chunks.en: Fresh graduate (æœ¬ç§‘) with 1.5 years of experience, wants to change environment but feels extremely inferior, what to do?

As the title says, I'd like to hear the opinions of you seniors.

**My situation**
My education is from a 985 university (æœ¬ç§‘ - Bachelor's degree). After graduation, I joined a unicorn company as a Java developer. The salary isn't particularly high, but it's acceptable. The atmosphere is a bit competitive, but compared to those sweatshops, it's considered a comfortable existence.

However, I'm working on backend projects within the company. I feel that the main difficulty of my daily tasks lies in the complex business processes, and there are no technical challenges. So, I feel that my technical skills are not being developed sufficiently, and there are not any technical challenges (basically just the classic interview questions).

**Problem**
I don't think it's bad to stay in this company for now, but personally, I'd like to go to a more challenging platform (a big company? or a C-end company with more traffic). I recently updated my resume and feel that my progress in the past year and a half has been very limited. In addition, memorizing interview questions gives me a headache. Over time, I have slowly fallen into a deep sense of powerlessness and inferiority. I feel that I am really too weak. What should I do?
I don't know if I should attach my resume. Let's write this much for now.
Height isn't the problem. Although 1.5 meters is a bit short, maintaining an optimistic attitude is the most important thing.
Having worked for three years, I also felt at the beginning that I needed to constantly improve myself and see more complex business scenarios in order to improve my technical skills.
But I gradually realized that technology has always served business and is also realized through business.
So, no matter how good the technology is, it's useless if the company doesn't make money. If the technology is garbage but the company makes money, then it's very easy.
Therefore, in the choice of work, you must choose a company with good business conditions and is not competitive.
Improving your personal abilities is naturally also necessary.
This improvement can be active exploration, actively optimizing business bottlenecks in the company, or restructuring. These are challenging and also difficult to promote.
But I think it is of great help to the improvement of personal abilities.
You can also expand horizontally according to your interests and then let your interests make money for you (using creativity to generate wealth, hahaha).
In addition, in the spirit of 'The world is a poorly assembled troupe', many things that look good are actually just so-so.
There are many subjects in life, so you may want to distribute your energy appropriately to some other areas.
Personally, I dislike the idea that 'there are no challenging technical problems at work, so you can't learn anything'.
For work, business and technology are complementary.
Technology is not only passively serving business, but also finding ways to provide extended and enhanced capabilities for business.
Moreover, learning is entirely your own business, and the company has no obligation to provide you with learning conditions.
You said 'the business process is complicated', have you ever thought about how to organize these complicated processes and make a more abstract and generalized design?
For example, use a workflow engine to abstract and unify all processes, or even create a general platform that allows the business to configure the process themselves.
In the process, you can help the business sort out the process, and you can also find points in the process that can be optimized and improved.
The goal of the work is set by the business, but how to complete the work is up to you.
If you can only see the work in front of you and think about passively learning technology by changing jobs, then when you finally can't change jobs, you will be locked in that company.
1.5 cm is indeed short
First step: Think about whether others can understand you before you speak.

Being short in height is really nothing, although it is more difficult to find a partner, there are still many girls below 1.5m, as long as you are a little taller than her, and you are excellent in all aspects, you can still find one. Also, learn to think from other people's perspectives and improve your language skills. For example, did you not look carefully at your title before you posted it?
Who can understand it?

0. [Bachelor/Master] + a number is a fairly common description method in the CN tech worker circle, expressing whether you have a bachelor's, master's, or doctoral degree and how many years you have worked. The people upstairs expressing that they don't know may not be looking at job search software enough;

chunks.en: 1. I myself have a 985 bachelor's degree with 2.5 years of experience, working for a big company as a Java developer. The things I do are not technically difficult, but I understand one thing: big companies, especially CN's internet giants, have business far outweighing technology. Regardless of whether I am qualified to work on Alibaba or Tencent's top open-source projects or backend high-pressure scenarios, 99% of things are business over technology. The role of product managers is far greater than programmers. So, as long as the business makes money, you have irreplaceable value, there is a clear promotion path, and you are satisfied with your salary, my advice is to keep going;

2. Technical improvement: The master leads you in, but your cultivation depends on yourself. Now I watch technical-related things and code some things using passion after work. I personally think that this is the technical improvement in the minds of most formally trained programmers. The company's business does not improve technology much. The company also hires me to complete work, and this work includes various aspects. Coding is just the tip of the iceberg, so technical improvement still depends on yourself.
A 985 undergraduate degree is a good starting point, and it is normal to be a cog in the machine at the company, so you just need to have the right mindset.

My personal opinion is that the biggest disadvantage of the coding industry is that you must continue to learn, but the biggest advantage is also that you can continue to learn. Not to mention, GitHub is a huge treasure trove. I haven't heard that other industries are so open.
When you are doing well on GitHub and find that you are great, you will naturally feel less inferior.
What does 'æœ¬ç§‘ 1.5' mean?
@wallriding #13 æœ¬ç§‘ 1.5 ..... Inferiority, of course, it's height! What else could it be...
Accept the things you cannot change with equanimity, and use self-deprecation to resolve inferiority. This is the best method. God-given bodies are different, it's not a big deal.
Work will not directly improve your technology, they are not equal, it will only improve your experience.
If you want to improve your technical level, there is only one way: self-directed learning.
Don't naively think that the training you get at work is your 'experience', not 'technology'.
Determine your goals. If it is to make more money, business skills are the most important, followed by relationships, management, emotional intelligence, etc.
If you just want to improve your technology, I advise you to stay in this company and learn independently, don't get yourself upset.
Look for a better horse while riding your donkey, you can talk about it when you find a better one.

Look for a better horse while riding the donkey, jump to a big company or a foreign company. You have an advantage in education. The interview is not difficult at this stage. Brush up on the algorithms and interview questions. The environment is just bad now. Don't feel inferior. Keep a calm attitude and you will always find it if you persevere.
Since you are already in a unicorn company, you can first consider how to get promoted within the company.

If you like technology, then compete for ratings; if you don't like technology, then consider how to develop into a management position; if you don't like either, then you can also use the company's resources to develop a side hustle.
@zwpaper Thank you very much, this is also an idea.
First submit your resume, and then wait for an opportunity to move when there is something better.
Just ignore the things you definitely cannot change.
Change the things you can change.

chunks.en: First look at the interview questions and memorize them. Submit your resume and go to the interview first. Don't think about what you can't do here. If you really think like this, you can think about how to build a rocket. The more you think, the more problems you have.
I have the same worries as OP ğŸ˜”. I plan to start submitting my resume after getting the year-end bonus after the new year.
